summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from March 9, 2020, covering multiple cases handled by the Southern District of New York (SDNY). The primary focus is on the Epstein investigation, specifically Prince Andrew's refusal to cooperate, and updates on the jail captain involved during Epstein's death. It also includes summaries of other unrelated cases: a major horse racing doping scandal, the hung jury in the CIA leak trial of Joshua Schulte, the arrest of Lawrence Ray for alleged sex trafficking, commentary on SDNY independence, criticism of Attorney General Barr, and an injury to Harvey Weinstein in jail.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Made public statements regarding Prince Andrew's non-cooperation in the Epstein investigation, announced indictments in the horse racing doping case, commented on SDNY's independence from political influence, and announced charges against Lawrence Ray.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: British royal, friend of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Reportedly declined to voluntarily cooperate with the U.S. investigation into Epstein's co-conspirators, despite a prior public offer. Denied allegations of sexual misconduct with an Epstein accuser.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker
persons.context: Deceased by suicide in August 2019 while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The investigation into his co-conspirators is ongoing.

persons.name: Jermaine Darden
persons.context: Was the captain in charge when Epstein died. Is being transferred to FCI Fort Dix as an 'emergency preparedness officer'.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: British socialite, longtime associate of Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as a focus of the FBI probe into individuals who facilitated Epstein's alleged trafficking of underage girls.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Accused of sleeping on the job and falsifying records the night of Epstein's death. Has pleaded not guilty.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Accused of sleeping on the job and falsifying records the night of Epstein's death. Has pleaded not guilty.

persons.name: Montell Figgins
persons.context: Criticized the transfer of Captain Darden as an example of upper ranks facing no consequences for systemic failures at MCC.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: Was warden during Epstein's suicide. Was moved to a desk job in Pennsylvania, with a planned transfer to Fort Dix put on hold by Attorney General Barr.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Ordered the transfer of former warden N'Diaye to be put on hold. Criticized in a judge's opinion for lack of candor and political independence regarding the Mueller report.

persons.name: Jorge Navarro
persons.role: Horse trainer, defendant in doping case
persons.context: Allegedly orchestrated an international horse doping scheme. His horse X Y Jet died after receiving numerous PEDs.

persons.name: Jason Servis
persons.role: Horse trainer, defendant in doping case
persons.context: Trainer of Maximum Security, indicted for conspiracy of drug adulteration and misbranding as part of the doping scheme.

persons.name: William F. Sweeney Jr.
persons.role: FBI Assistant Director in Charge, New York Office
persons.context: Commented on the cruelty and abuse to horses in the doping case, calling it the most far-reaching prosecution of its kind.

persons.name: Joshua Schulte
persons.context: Trial for leaking CIA documents to WikiLeaks ended in a hung jury on major counts. Convicted on contempt of court and false statements charges.

persons.name: Sabrina Shroff
persons.context: Represented Schulte at trial, argued about withheld information regarding a witness and security vulnerabilities at the CIA.

persons.name: Lawrence Ray
persons.context: Arrested and charged with sex trafficking, forced labor, and extortion, allegedly involving his daughter's college friends. Case discussed in context of pre-trial publicity.

persons.name: Danielle Sassoon
persons.context: Described financial ledgers allegedly showing high earnings from prostitution by a victim in the Lawrence Ray case.

persons.name: Harvey Weinstein
persons.context: Reportedly injured after a fall at Rikers Island jail, complaining of head pain. Awaiting sentencing.

persons.name: Juda Englemayer
persons.context: Spoke to Weinstein by phone and relayed details of his jail injury and state of mind.

persons.name: Reggie Walton
persons.context: Issued a scathing opinion questioning Attorney General William Barr's credibility and political independence regarding the Mueller report.

persons.name: Clare Montgomery
persons.context: Reportedly represents Prince Andrew on matters related to Epstein, declined to comment.

persons.name: James Margolin
persons.role: Spokesman for U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: Declined comment on options being considered regarding Prince Andrew's non-cooperation.

persons.name: Brendan Pierson
persons.context: Co-author of the Reuters article on Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Mark Hosenball
persons.context: Co-author of the Reuters article on Prince Andrew.

connections.description: Described as a friend; Prince Andrew socialized with Epstein and has called the association 'ill-judged'.
Maxwell is described as a longtime associate of Epstein's, and the FBI probe is focusing on her and others who facilitated his alleged trafficking.
Darden, as captain, oversaw lieutenants and correctional officers including Noel.
Darden, as captain, oversaw lieutenants and correctional officers including Thomas.
Figgins is the defense attorney for correctional officer Michael Thomas.
Tension exists between Berman (SDNY US Attorney) and Barr (Attorney General) over case management and independence.
Both high-profile trainers indicted in the same horse racing doping conspiracy; discussed PEDs in an intercepted call.
Sassoon is the prosecutor presenting evidence (financial ledgers) against Ray in court.

events.title: Prince Andrew Declines Cooperation
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman announces that Britain's Prince Andrew has 'completely shut the door' on voluntarily cooperating with the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's co-conspirators.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at 6:30 a.m.

events.title: Horse Racing Doping Indictments
events.description: Federal prosecutors unseal indictments against 27 individuals, including trainers and veterinarians, in an international racehorse doping scheme described as the largest ever by the DOJ.

events.title: Joshua Schulte Trial Ends in Hung Jury
events.description: The trial of former CIA programmer Joshua Schulte, accused of leaking classified documents to WikiLeaks, ends with a hung jury on the major counts. He was convicted on contempt and false statements charges.

events.title: Arrest of Lawrence Ray
events.description: Lawrence Ray is arrested at his home in Piscataway, NJ, and charged with sex trafficking, forced labor, and extortion involving his daughter's college friends.

events.title: Harvey Weinstein Injured in Jail
events.description: Harvey Weinstein falls and is injured while at Rikers Island jail, complaining of head pain and possible concussion.

events.title: Judge Criticizes Attorney General Barr
events.description: Federal Judge Reggie Walton issues an opinion questioning Attorney General William Barr's credibility and political independence regarding his public characterization of the Mueller report.

keyFacts: Prince Andrew formally declined to voluntarily cooperate with the U.S. investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's co-conspirators, despite a prior public offer.
Jermaine Darden, the MCC captain in charge when Epstein died, was being transferred to a new position at FCI Fort Dix, which critics cited as a lack of accountability.
The FBI's investigation into Epstein's network was focusing on Ghislaine Maxwell and others who facilitated the alleged trafficking.
A major international horse racing doping scandal was announced, with 27 individuals indicted for administering dangerous PEDs to horses.
The trial of Joshua Schulte for leaking CIA documents to WikiLeaks ended in a hung jury on the most serious charges.
